questions.question: Which UNESCO site in Peru features an Inca citadel that was rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911, known as the 'Lost City of the Incas'?
questions.context: Machu Picchu is an iconic symbol of the Inca Empire and was built in the 15th century on a mountain ridge above the Sacred Valley.

questions.question: At what UNESCO World Heritage Site in France was the famous Gothic cathedral with impressive flying buttresses built over the span of nearly a century starting in 1163?
questions.context: Notre-Dame Cathedral is renowned for its historic and architectural significance, including its stained-glass windows and its role during the coronation of Napoleon Bonaparte.

questions.question: Which UNESCO designated historical site in Turkey served as the final stronghold of the Byzantine Empire, famously falling in the year 1453?
questions.context: Hagia Sophia was originally constructed as a cathedral in the 6th century under Emperor Justinian I and later became a mosque, now operating as a museum.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Egypt was originally constructed over a 20-year period around 2560 BC as a tomb for Pharaoh Khufu?
questions.context: The Great Pyramid is the only one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still in existence and is located near Cairo.

questions.question: Which UNESCO site in China, extending over 13,000 miles, was primarily constructed as a defense against invasions and has sections dating back to the 7th century BC?
questions.context: The Great Wall traverses mountains, valleys, and deserts, featuring bastions, watchtowers, and fortresses built in various eras primarily during the Ming dynasty.
